Based on the search results, I found several educational resources and discussions about Wuthering Heights for young audiences, teens, and high school students. Here's what I discovered:

## Educational YouTube Content and Teaching Resources

Study.com offers a 5-minute video lesson that provides a summary of Wuthering Heights and explores its setting, with key themes and a quiz for knowledge testing. Shmoop also has a video summary that presents Heathcliff in an accessible way, noting that while he may not be as romantic as Mr. Darcy, viewers will still find him compelling despite his self-serving and revengeful nature.

## Teaching Guides and High School Relevance

TeacherVision provides a comprehensive teachers' guide on Wuthering Heights with discussion questions and chapter summaries. Most importantly, the themes of Wuthering Heights appeal to teenage students, as the power relationships involving romantic love and vengeance depicted in the novel are part of high school students' social environment, and teachers who make relevant connections between the novel's themes and students' concerns find it opens up meaningful discussion.

## Modern Adaptations for Teen Audiences

There's a modern adaptation called "Wuthering High School" (2015) that is set in Malibu, California, and follows the passionate but destructive romance between wealthy teen Cathy and her father's troubled new ward, Heath. However, this adaptation has an uncertain target audience - while the modern setting and young characters suggest it's geared toward teens, the destructive relationship at its heart makes it problematic, as impressionable teens might mistake the destructive central relationship for an enviable one.

## Student Reviews and Reception

Common Sense Media features kid and teen reviews of Wuthering Heights, and some students report reading Wuthering Heights as part of English Extension classes in high school.

## Kate Bush Connection for Young Audiences

Interestingly, many literature teachers show Kate Bush's 1978 "Wuthering Heights" music video when teaching the novel, as it speaks directly to students about life's bigger questions and validates young people's artistic impulses, arguing that teenagers don't need to wait for their ideas and art to matter.

The search results suggest there are educational video resources available, though specific YouTube channels weren't prominently featured. The emphasis appears to be on making the classic novel accessible and relevant to modern teens through various educational platforms and teaching approaches.
